doc.after: On July 2, 1947, the Polish government passed a law establishing a state memorial to the victims of Nazism on the site of the camp.[73] In 1955, an exhibition opened displaying prisoner mug shots; hair, suitcases, and shoes taken from murdered prisoners; canisters of Zyklon B pellets; and other objects related to the killings.[200] UNESCO added the camp to its list of World Heritage Sites in 1979.[201] In 2011, the museum drew 1,400,000 visitors.[202]
